## Quick summary
When I access the Patch Manager menu with the default stylesheet, the checkboxes are not visible.

![screenshot 19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69492745/89850789-fad3a200-db58-11ea-958b-52c26454fe39.jpg)



* OS: Arch Linux x86_64
* CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 3700X
* GPU: RTX 2070 Super 
* Driver version: 450.57

**How to reproduce:** Run gs_gcm_cube.elf with Shader Interpreter only mode. Also happens with commercial games on ASync with Shader Interpreter mode.

**Debug validation layers output**

```
E {RSX [0x00016d0]} RSX: ERROR: [Validation] Code 0 : Validation Error: [ VUID-VkImageViewCreateInfo-subResourceRange-01021 ] Object 0: handle = 0xa9fc120000000168, type = VK_OBJECT_TYPE_IMAGE; | MessageID = 0x835d4826 | vkCreateImageView(): pCreateInfo->viewType VK_IMAGE_VIEW_TYPE_3D is not compatible with image type VK_IMAGE_TYPE_2D. The Vulkan spec states: subresourceRange and viewType must be compatible with the image, as described in the compatibility table (https://vulkan.lunarg.com/doc/view/1.2.141.0/windows/1.2-extensions/vkspec.html#VUID-VkImageViewCreateInfo-subResourceRange-01021)
E {RSX [0x00016d0]} RSX: ERROR: [Validation] Code 0 : Validation Error: [ VUID-VkImageViewCreateInfo-viewType-02960 ] Object 0: handle = 0x108715510, type = VK_OBJECT_TYPE_DEVICE; | MessageID = 0xfcc34056 | vkCreateImageView(): subresourceRange.layerCount (1) must be 6 or VK_REMAINING_ARRAY_LAYERS. The Vulkan spec states: If viewType is VK_IMAGE_VIEW_TYPE_CUBE and subresourceRange.layerCount is not VK_REMAINING_ARRAY_LAYERS, subresourceRange.layerCount must be 6 (https://vulkan.lunarg.com/doc/view/1.2.141.0/windows/1.2-extensions/vkspec.html#VUID-VkImageViewCreateInfo-viewType-02960)
E {RSX [0x00016d0]} RSX: ERROR: [Validation] Code 0 : Validation Error: [ VUID-VkImageViewCreateInfo-image-01003 ] Object 0: handle = 0xa9fc120000000168, type = VK_OBJECT_TYPE_IMAGE; | MessageID = 0x13c91c20 | vkCreateImageView(): pCreateInfo->viewType VK_IMAGE_VIEW_TYPE_CUBE is not compatible with image type VK_IMAGE_TYPE_2D. The Vulkan spec states: If image was not created with VK_IMAGE_CREATE_CUBE_COMPATIBLE_BIT then viewType must not be VK_IMAGE_VIEW_TYPE_CUBE or VK_IMAGE_VIEW_TYPE_CUBE_ARRAY (https://vulkan.lunarg.com/doc/view/1.2.141.0/windows/1.2-extensions/vkspec.html#VUID-VkImageViewCreateInfo-image-01003)
```

This happens to work fine on AMD and NVIDIA Windows proprietary drivers despite the validation errors. On Mesa anv, it will assert the driver. Currently, any commercial game when used with Shader Interpreter will assert anv.

**System information**

Mesa: mesa-git 20.2.0_devel.126358.323d5bbfd9a-1
OS: 5.7.9-1-MANJARO
CPU: Intel i7-6700HQ
GPU: Intel HD 530 (Skylake GT2)

There are currently some shaders that are being compiled every run while using OpenGL. Verified that this does not happen on Vulkan. This happens regardless of Sync / ASync shader modes. Also happens regardless of `mesa_glthread`.

When testing Yakuza 3 Demo, this is consistent for 1 shader right before the first SEGA intro screen, and for 15-20 shaders when going in-game to the first scene without starting to move around. Moving around will cause more shaders to be compiled again.

Even with a full shader cache, this happens every single time consistently with the same shaders.
Completing the demo and going back into the game without rebooting the game doesn't cause the shaders to be recompiled again.

Log file from running the game up to the SEGA title screen, with a preloaded shader cache:
[RPCS3.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/4975032/RPCS3.zip)

Test environment: 

```
RPCS3 v0.0.11-10682-917069e3 Alpha | HEAD | Firmware version: 4.85
Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700HQ CPU @ 2.60GHz | 8 Threads | 15.52 GiB RAM | TSC: 2.592GHz | AVX+ | FMA3 | TSX-FA
Operating system: POSIX, Name: Linux, Release: 5.7.9-1-MANJARO, Version: #1 SMP PREEMPT Thu Jul 16 08:20:05 UTC 2020
·! 0:00:00.000000 SYS: Initialization times before main(): 0.045907s
·! 0:00:00.161223 RSX: Found vulkan-compatible GPU: 'Intel(R) HD Graphics 530 (SKL GT2)' running on driver 20.1.99
```
`mesa-git 20.2.0_devel.126358.323d5bbfd9a-1`, iris driver

It's really cool that the "Create PPU Cache" option finally seems to work as intended.

But sadly the created cache seems to have a different hash than the normal cache that is created on **disc** game boot.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23019877/83353659-5cef7a00-a354-11ea-8313-40124ddc1cae.png)

This means that you basically have to create the cache on boot again anyway, and the prior created cache is not used.

EDIT: This seems to be happening on disc games with updates only (afaict)

## Details
The texture is in B8G8R8A8_UNORM and optimal tiling. The fragment shader just samples the texture straight onto screen, so it shouldn't be the shader's problem. This looks like a texture format issue to me, but I don't know how RSX works so I am not sure.

I don't have time to dig down further, but I hope the corruption pattern will ring a bell to people who are familiar with RSX like @kd-11.

observation: The chronicles of riddick dark athena runs on the same engine (albeit newer) and renders bloom and colors correctly.

Vulkan compute descriptor allocation is suboptimal, making large RSX captures impossible to replay. Either the compute-based texture decoder should be possible to disable or the allocation should be dynamic to avoid this situation.

I have an Intel Iris Plus 640 iGPU and am using driver `26.20.100.6861`. Starting FIFA 15 with Vulkan freezes my PC for a couple of seconds, OpenGL is fine. After I regain control, the render window stopped responding and stopping the emulator gives me the deadlock notice.

```
·E {RSX [0x00a92d8]} RSX: ERROR: [Validation] Code 0 :  [ VUID-vkResetFences-pFences-01123 ] Object: 0xf00fbe00000000db (Type = 7) | VkFence 0xf00fbe00000000db[] is in use. The Vulkan spec states: Each element of pFences must not be currently associated with any queue command that has not yet completed execution on that queue (https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.1-extensions/html/vkspec.html#VUID-vkResetFences-pFences-01123)
·E {RSX [0x00a92d8]} RSX: ERROR: [Validation] Code 0 :  [ VUID-vkResetDescriptorPool-descriptorPool-00313 ] Object: 0x1a4b4e000000012c (Type = 22) | It is invalid to call vkResetDescriptorPool() with descriptor sets in use by a command buffer. The Vulkan spec states: All uses of descriptorPool (via any allocated descriptor sets) must have completed execution (https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.1-extensions/html/vkspec.html#VUID-vkResetDescriptorPool-descriptorPool-00313)
```

I don't know if this is a driver issue or some feature RPCS3 needs but bisecting the drivers and comparing the output of vulkancapsviewer gives me this:
| | 26.20.100.7463 | 26.20.100.7529 | 
|---|:-:|:-:|
| `VK_KHR_shader_float_controls` | - | v4 |
| maxStorageBufferRange | 134217728 | 4294967295 |
| minStorageBufferOffsetAlignment | 0x10 | 0x40 |
| minTexelBufferOffsetAlignment | 0x10 | 0x40 |
| minUniformBufferOffsetAlignment | 0x20 | 0x40 |
| optimalBufferCopyOffsetAlignment | 0x10 | 0x40 |
| optimalBufferCopyRowPitchAlignment | 0x10 | 0x40 |

Please let me know if this is worth investigating or if I should just use a newer driver / OpenGL for that particular game. I would really like to stay on `26.20.100.6861` if possible.

P.S. it freezes right before the _EA SPORTS - It's in the game_ video so it might be related to that.

This doesn't have any pratical effect but it's a security issue.

How to reproduce:
- Boot /dev_flash/pspemu/psp_emulator.self directly (no argv[1] - path to psp game)

The emulator will attempt accessing Host's /host_root/, and while RPCS3 correctly returns CELL_ENOTMOUNTED, the emulator is able to access Host's full emulator path regardless. **Guest applications must not be able to peek into Host's paths while host_root is not mounted.**

Example from log:
```
E {PPU[0x1000000] Thread (main_thread) [0x002d09ac]} SYS: '_sys_prx_load_module' failed with 0x8001003a : CELL_ENOTMOUNTED, /host_root//home/ani/.config/rpcs3/dev_flash/pspemu/release/sysmem.sprx [1]
```

This game is plagued by serious smoke problems. When it's serious, nothing can be seen (only smoke full of the screen, especially STAGE 2). I hope transparency of smoke can be fixed soon.

## Quick summary
Heavenly Sword seems to be pretty perfect aside from the shadows that display improperly. It's a weird phenomenon where, as you move closer towards shadows, they regress and disappear. The same thing happens to the entire area if you move the camera; shadows will shift and move around the entire area. Basically, as you move around, the shadows are constantly shifting and wrapping around the entire area. 

## Details
Using a Ryzen 3950x and RTX 2080 Super. Win 10.
RSX Log: https://mega.nz/#!cfhVgKzZ

## Quick summary
Upon loading into the tutorial, the player cannot interact with the target object, after exiting the tutorial and selecting the craft, the game hangs in the loading screen with this problem in the console:

F` 0:08:03.641753 {RSX [0x0030438]} sig_log: Thread terminated due to fatal error: Unknown stencil op 0x6
(in file `C:\projects\rpcs3\rpcs3\Emu\RSX\gcm_enums.cpp:695)

## Quick summary
When booting the game, if there is any save data for it, it crashes on intro (auto loading settings, user profile, etc). Without save data, it is perfectly playable.

## Details
RPCS3 v0.0.8-9568-bcbe3245 Alpha | HEAD | FW 4.85 | Windows 10 1909
Intel Core i9-9900K | 16 Threads | 15.86 GiB RAM | AVX+ | TSX-FA
GPU: GeForce RTX 2080 (442.19)

On current master the game boots fine and is playable as long as there is no save data for BCUS98180 in `dev_hdd0\home\00000001\savedata`. If there is any save data such as a user profile or settings that the game tries to automatically load, it crashes with the following error: `VM: Access violation reading location 0xd2d0a0a0`

This issue was initially reported as a regression as #5798. However, after doing some testing myself, this has always been an issue and the PR blamed in that issue actually changed nothing. I even went back and tested on 0.0.5-6906 and I was able to replicate this issue. That author also seemingly abandoned the issue and closed it for no reason, as I have yet to see any build in which this issue does not occur. This is and always has been an issue. When booting disc games with updates installed, "Boot with Global Configuration" still uses settings from game-specific configuration. These games first try to boot from the disc and then switch to HDD to run the updated executable, my theory is that this confuses the emulator and causes it to lose track of the global config preference.

Here's a log of a game that was had renderer set to null in custom config and vulkan in global. The game booted with nothing being rendered.
[RPCS3.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/4173928/RPCS3.log.gz)

After closing a game, RPCS3 doesn't seem to free all the memory that was used by it. This causes memory usage to continue growing until the emulator is restarted, which can end up filling RAM after running some games a few times. My test subject here was getting to the menu in Spec Ops The Line, but it seems to happen in all the games I've tested that don't cause an emu crash after closing.

First boot:
Usage ingame: ~1.8GB
Usage after closing the game: ~1.5GB

Second boot: 
Usage ingame: ~2.6GB
Usage after closing the game: ~2.3GB

...and so on until you either notice, or you fill memory.

Log in case it's of any use:
[RPCS3.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/4173654/RPCS3.log.gz)

This is running on popOS by the way, haven't checked this behavior on Windows, but I'd assume it also happens there.

fusermount: old style mounting not supported

if you run it with the --appimage-extract option. 
See https://github.com/AppImage/AppImageKit/wiki/FUSE 
for more information
open dir error: No such file or directory
```

OS: Manjaro 18.1.5

Bug:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10283761/73987515-911fd480-4938-11ea-93c6-f2f7530e2c50.png)

Did some QA with a friend, both controllers happened to disconnect and reconnect in the opposite order as pads were defined. So both pads disconnected and when reconnecting Player 2's controller connected to Player 1's pad and Player 1's controller connected to Player 2's pad.

The controllers were both DualShock 4, but I'm not sure if it's relevant to the issue, seems like it can happen with any controller type.

It's obvious why this happens, since the game is essentially being booted. However, when used as an "All titles" option, it resets all games' Last Played dates to the current date. It also adds extra time on playtime, but that doesn't seem very relevant.

Curiously, NASCAR 09 Demo seems to overwrite its own param.sfo on the first boot, marking itself as Game Data (on the first boot, it is properly recognized as HDD Game). This results in the game being playable only once, after that it has to be reinstalled.

Looking at the code, `cellGameDataCheckCreate2` appears to be the offender - to make matters worse, it cannot handle param.sfo being read-only, so an attempt to prevent the game from "commiting suicide" like this will instead result in an exception being thrown.

Attaching a log file from the first boot and param.sfo before/after "suicide":
[RPCS3.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/4144343/RPCS3.log.gz)
[param.sfo-before.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/4144344/param.sfo-before.zip)
[param.sfo-after.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/4144346/param.sfo-after.zip)

I've encountered an issue with the emulator itself, not any specific game.  Other people have said they're not affected by this, so it must be another edge case.

When using the LLVM SPU recompiler, it stops compiling the SPU cache on boot at around 75% and throws an Unhandled Exception error, but only when the SPU cache has reached about 3500 modules or more.  For example, Sly Cooper: Thieves in Time loads fine with the LLVM SPU recompiler when the SPU cache had around 3100 modules, but on the next boot it had just under 7000 modules and throws the Unhandled Exception error.  All of the 24 games in my library are affected by this, even ones in the Playable category such as Skate 3.

All my drivers have been updated, virus/malware/rootkit scans come up clean, Windows has been updated.  All pre-requisites have been installed, too.  This has affected me for the past 10+ builds of RPCS3.  Also, this prevents the emulator from creating a compressed (.gz) version of the log, so I'll be providing the uncompressed (.txt) version as that's all I'll get.

Specs:

Windows 10 Pro 64-bit
Alienware Aurora R5
Intel Core i7-6700K CPU @ 4.00 GHz (8 CPUs)
16384 MB RAM
NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080
Running on a Samsung EVO 860 2TB SSD (Games also stored on this drive)

Moving the emulator folder out of Program Files didn't fix this.
[RPCS3.log](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/3898154/RPCS3.log)

I'm getting a segmentation fault when I start a game using the `--no-gui` option. Same game runs fine without this option.

1. Open a terminal

Commit 4599d5841353fdf8096191c30a592fedc844efce an incomplete/incorrect fix.

In IdManager.h, `id_traits` has its static variables assigned inline, right where they are declared.  This is incorrect unless the `inline` keyword is used.  I'm not a C++ expert but the current code may violate the One Definition Rule.  Without the `inline` keyword, the linkage works strangely, which is the source of the undefined reference error on debug builds.

One solution besides `inline` would be out-of line declarations of the static variables, but this is tricky because of the `void_t`.  Once implemented, this solution causes gcc to complain about the use of non-`contexpr` variables in the `static_assert`, so it does not work.

The best solution IMO is to replace the `const` keyword with `constexpr` for `base`, `step`, `count`, and `invalid` in both specializations of `id_traits`.  This makes the `static_assert` in the second class template valid, and it also fixes the undefined reference error.

Regardless, a new local variable in the destructor of `sys_vm_t` is not a good fix.

https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/f7842b765f0490e85a993eb84515c911fb426ccd/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKGSRender.cpp#L2743-L2747
https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/f7842b765f0490e85a993eb84515c911fb426ccd/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKGSRender.cpp#L2754-L2755

If this branch is taken, then either `m_vertex_layout_storage` was null or `m_vertex_layout_storage->in_range` returned false. In both cases, `base_offset` is still uninitialized by the time its value is read on lines 2754 and 2755.

This behavior was introduced by commit 6a32f716db2dc5989b1c3802c55317455b157043.

Hi! I've found a regression that seemed to have appeared in 0.0.7-8934 build (previous build 0.0.7-8926 works fine). On the download page, this build is linked to this PR: https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/pull/6790.
Basically, this regression made animations in the Netflix app running with Vulkan backend to have the same kind of graphical issues that OpenGL backend has. 
Most notably it makes loading circle "wobble".

RPCS3 version: 0.0.7-8901 Alpha (commit 0fe46934de258826e72bfb00eb20c606d0a635cd) OS: Arch Linux (x86_64), kernel v5.3.6-arch1 Steps to reproduce: - Enable Vulkan in GPU settings. - Start any game. Expected behavior: The game starts. Actual behavior: RPCS3 sometimes crashes after it has loaded precompiled shaders, but before the games starts. Other times, it silently corrupts the heap but works anyway.
Here's what I believe is going on: - `render_target::get_resolve_target_safe` allocates a `vk::viewable_image` called `resolve_surface`. https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/0fe46934de258826e72bfb00eb20c606d0a635cd/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKRenderTargets.h#L31 - `render_target::resolve` calls `vk::resolve_image` with `resolve_surface` as `dst`. https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/0fe46934de258826e72bfb00eb20c606d0a635cd/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKRenderTargets.h#L92 - `vk::resolve_image` calls `vk::as_rtt` on `dst`. https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/0fe46934de258826e72bfb00eb20c606d0a635cd/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKResolveHelper.cpp#L106 - `vk::as_rtt` casts `dst` to a `vk::render_target`, which it is **not**. https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/0fe46934de258826e72bfb00eb20c606d0a635cd/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKRenderTargets.h#L544 - Undefined behavior ensues, and memory corruption leads to unpredictable program operation.
From [cppreference](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/static_cast), under conversion number 2: > Such static_cast makes no runtime checks to ensure that the object's runtime type is actually D, and may only be used safely if this precondition is guaranteed by other means, such as when implementing static polymorphism. Safe downcast may be done with dynamic_cast. Since RPCS3 implements no safety mechanism for this cast, it would make sense to follow the above recommendation and use `dynamic_cast`. This is a simple patch that would accomplish this: ```diff diff --git a/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/GL/GLRenderTargets.h b/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/GL/GLRenderTargets.h index f3060ea8e..932972a8b 100644 --- a/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/GL/GLRenderTargets.h +++ b/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/GL/GLRenderTargets.h @@ -119,7 +119,7 @@ namespace gl static inline gl::render_target* as_rtt(gl::texture* t) { - return reinterpret_cast(t); + return &dynamic_cast(*t); } } diff --git a/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKRenderTargets.h b/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKRenderTargets.h index 287b9eb68..a5805ef1a 100644 --- a/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKRenderTargets.h +++ b/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKRenderTargets.h @@ -541,7 +541,7 @@ namespace vk static inline vk::render_target* as_rtt(vk::image* t) { - return static_cast(t); + return &dynamic_cast(*t); } } ``` This uses `dynamic_cast` on a reference so that instead of unpredictable memory corruption, you get a reliable `std::bad_cast` exception in the RPCS3 console. `gl::as_rtt` performs a similar cast (with `reinterpret_cast` for some reason), which should also use `dynamic_cast`. Obviously, the bug is still there, it is just reliably caught this way.

Having MSAA enabled causes some weird graphical glitches in Metal Gear Solid 3 that I'd like to demonstrate:

The intro section with MSAA enabled:
![screenshot-2019_10_13_23_16_37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54376483/66758241-913a2700-eea6-11e9-9f0c-d0ae266fdd85.png)

The intro section with MSAA disabled:
![screenshot-2019_10_14_17_01_38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54376483/66758268-a2833380-eea6-11e9-9835-4b2110e765f3.png)

Enabling anti-aliasing is somewhat necessary since it also fixes some missing graphics such as:
- The cockpit showing incorrectly when MSAA is disabled:
![screenshot-2019_10_14_17_01_23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54376483/66758633-5389ce00-eea7-11e9-94e8-68c8490108e4.png)


- The same scene showing correctly with MSAA enabled:
![screenshot-2019_10_14_17_03_51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54376483/66758405-e0805780-eea6-11e9-9ebf-238c44591414.png)

Creating RSX captures of these screens crashes the emulator so I had to use Renderdoc instead.
The Renderdoc captures were done on an RX 570 with the latest drivers on Windows. (Though I'd like to mention that this issue is the same on Linux as well with RADV)

The Renderdoc with MSAA disabled: https://drive.google.com/open?id=18mRM3XpIDJs2y2Xc1LbqbM2WIq-cOTMl

Edit: Re-opened the issue (miss-click-closed the old thread #6714 )

As suggested by @clienthax manually setting the audio output to "disabled" inside RPCS3s settings fixed this fatal error. But in reality I'd like this to occur automatically.

Imo RPCS3 should check if there is any valid audio output option available upon start up. And if there is none it should default to "Null" and grey out the "Audio Out" tab in RPCS3s audio settings. And there could also be a seperated dedicated option that lets you choose what device the audio should play from (in cases where someone has more than 1 audio device connected to the pc, like lets say a TV and some Headphones).

Hello, I got helped in the Discord #help channel and was told to open an issue for this.

Issue: 
To unlock songs in Rock Band 2, you have to play "Tour" mode. Doing so requires creating a character, which requires naming a character. When attempting to do this with a guitar controller connected, the game fails to return from text entry correctly. Whether you use "native" or Qt dialog for text entry, the screen won't brighten again (from the dimmed state during text entry) and the game will not proceed, soft-locked.

Reproduction steps:
1) Launch Rock Band 2 [BLES00385 v1.02] on RPCS3 with a RedOctane Gibson X-Plorer guitar connected via USB.
2) Select "Tour" mode from the main menu. Select to create a new band, which requires creating a new character.
3) Select the first menu option to name your new character, and press enter to select the default name (or enter any name, it doesn't matter).
4) Observe that the game or emulator fails to return from the dim text entry screen. The game will not accept any input at this point and the emulation must be stopped and restarted.

Notes:
This issue doesn't occur when a standard Xbox One controller is connected. Both ASMJIT and LLVM encounter the issue. TSX status (disabled/enabled) doesn't matter. I thought the problem might be the missing analog axes on the guitar, but the issue also does NOT occur with my arcade stick, which has no input for the analog axes. The guitar does use one analog axis for whammy bar input, which is usually at the minimum value, but fiddling with the whammy bar during name entry didn't seem to impact the issue.

**Original issue description:**

When loading shaders the emulator sometimes uses the wrong background images: e.g. `ICON0.PNG` instead of `PIC1.PNG`. This is due to the fact that when an update is installed (or the game has copied part of its files over to the harddrive?) the place the game is started from changes, so `Emu.GetSfoDir()` resolves to a directory in `/dev_hdd0/` (instead of the boot directory), where the game might not have copied `PIC1.PNG` over to. (kudos to @AniLeo for figuring it out)

https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/13671d9684ce77321ba003f8acaf43f602b46d82/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/Overlays/overlay_message_dialog.cpp#L50-L57

This issue can be easily reproduced with games like Red Dead Redemption or Drakengard 3.

Image of the issue:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/61327076-69401680-a818-11e9-8e6e-f12452f36bf5.png)

Proof that `PIC1.PNG` exists:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/61327326-f4211100-a818-11e9-9f80-b4366316cd65.png)

Proof that `PIC1.PNG` doesn't exist where the game is actually launching from (due to an update):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/61327380-0f8c1c00-a819-11e9-86ad-909260850dbe.png)

Image of TLOU working correctly:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/61327243-bfad5500-a818-11e9-85f0-2d96a75c7320.png)

Image of TLOU having the `PIC1.PNG` in the current launch directory as well:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/61327445-38141600-a819-11e9-8691-08f3ed73dff1.png)

**Edit:** Found the PR that broke it: #5370 via [this commit.](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/commit/32059bfaa2aeab9dece0a32d196cddb6622e2994#diff-d276ce37dab441a896a433482258e59a)
- - -

**Updated issue description:**

Looks like the way `Emu.GetSfoDir()` works causes other problems as well. I noticed recently in one of kd's PRs that a user has a weirdly named game, and it felt oddly familiar:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/61565874-adcaec80-aa7a-11e9-9314-7dc341e0e03d.png)

I also remembered having issues like that, and then it dawned on me: since the title is also pulled out from the same directory (more specifically, from `PARAM.SFO` in that exact directory), if the update has it's own name, the game will now use that - and that's also arguably not the expected behaviour.

I have no records of a PSN title doing this, but I can very much imagine it happening as well. I'd recommend overhauling how `Emu.GetSfoDir()` and such functions work, because as is they cause mix-ups.

#### Version (commit hash) of RPCS3 you are using.
rpcs3-v0.0.6-8271-517a2bc3_linux64.AppImage

#### Issue to be reproduced.
Having Multiple driver install result in multiple same name gpu resulting in being unable to select specific (newer) driver.

```
GPU0
VkPhysicalDeviceProperties:
===========================
        apiVersion     = 0x401060  (1.1.96)
        driverVersion  = 79691781 (0x4c00005)
        vendorID       = 0x8086
        deviceID       = 0x0166
        deviceType     = INTEGRATED_GPU
        deviceName     = Intel(R) Ivybridge Mobile

...
irrelevent info removed
...

FORMAT_D32_SFLOAT_S8_UINT:
        linearTiling   FormatFeatureFlags:
                None
        optimalTiling  FormatFeatureFlags:
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_DEPTH_STENCIL_ATTACHMENT_BIT
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_BLIT_SRC_BIT
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_BLIT_DST_BIT
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_TRANSFER_SRC_BIT_KHR
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_TRANSFER_DST_BIT_KHR
        bufferFeatures FormatFeatureFlags:
                None
```

```
GPU1
VkPhysicalDeviceProperties:
===========================
        apiVersion     = 0x401066  (1.1.102)
        driverVersion  = 79695971 (0x4c01063)
        vendorID       = 0x8086
        deviceID       = 0x0166
        deviceType     = INTEGRATED_GPU
        deviceName     = Intel(R) Ivybridge Mobile

...
irrelevent info removed
...

FORMAT_D32_SFLOAT_S8_UINT:
        linearTiling   FormatFeatureFlags:
                None
        optimalTiling  FormatFeatureFlags:
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_SAMPLED_IMAGE_BIT
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_DEPTH_STENCIL_ATTACHMENT_BIT
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_BLIT_SRC_BIT
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_BLIT_DST_BIT
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_TRANSFER_SRC_BIT_KHR
                VK_FORMAT_FEATURE_TRANSFER_DST_BIT_KHR
        bufferFeatures FormatFeatureFlags:
                None
```

##### Cause:
RPCS3 just use the name and not the driver version.
https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/790962425cfb893529f72b3ef0dd1424fcc42973/rpcs3/rpcs3qt/emu_settings.cpp#L165
So only the first gpu with the same name is selected.
https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/790962425cfb893529f72b3ef0dd1424fcc42973/rpcs3/rpcs3qt/emu_settings.cpp#L76-L78

#### System specs.
Some old Gen 7 intel cpu which probably isn't enough to run RPCS3 anyway but one could always hope.

#### Additional info
I gotten the error `No hardware support for z24s8`.
Which the required feature should just been added a few days ago.

https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/blob/517a2bc34a6479ed011dff64d215c47dfae64614/rpcs3/Emu/RSX/VK/VKFormats.cpp#L18-L21

That's the reason I had multiple drivers.
https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=99493

After recent commits in the past few days, I can't start a new game in Drakengard 3 with SPU LLVM, RPCS3 just freezes and needs to be killed.

I see this in the console right before that happens:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12925873/57179578-d0336d80-6e6e-11e9-84b0-3be87bfa8657.png)

Here's a log file: 

[RPCS3.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/3144467/RPCS3.zip)

This issue is a bit weird.

I was doing some profiling of rpcs3 performance when I noticed that the rsx thread was spending a lot of time in libQt5. 
![qt5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26352541/57176285-3e9f0e00-6e24-11e9-8b14-11182f89a9c1.png)

Switching over to opengl quickly showed that it wasn't spending any time at all in Qt. First I tried downloading the appimage build to see if it was a problem with my qt libs, but the appimage showed the same issue. 

I then did some digging and nailed it down to the "check_window_status" function in VKGSRender.cpp

Commenting out the function led to performance getting a massive boost under vulkan when the rsx thread was under load. Now next to no time is being spent in Qt and resizing the window still seems to work most of the time. (I did get it to bug out though with keyrepeat rate set to 1000 times a second while holding down alt+enter) 

I then went to see if it was reproducible under windows. I launched into ninja gaiden sigma, and found the performance to be even lower than on linux. I then set out to install visual studio and comment out the function there as well. I had expected it to be a much bigger problem on windows since the function that gets called there is so much bigger.

In the end though, I couldn't see any performance gain from commenting it out under windows... it did make me unable to resize the window though, as expected. Launching it again with the visual studio profiler showed no real amount of time spent in Qt. 

2 things were made evident though: windows performance on ninja gaiden sigma is not good enough in the demanding areas (small usleep values requiring too much overhead?), and linux spends way too much cpu time with "check_window_status" structured the way it is.

Persona 5 misses the upscale filtering at the upper half of the image on both vendors' cards, and repeats the last line of the FBO right into the middle, creating a horizontal line effect dividing the upper and lower half of the image output.

The horizontal line issue has been long known but had been swept under the rug. Only occurs while upscaling, with 150% vs 200% showing no difference, all configurations (integer and non-integer modes) are affected.

Try looking at Joker's chin if you don't see any one of the issues.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/53355180-c2221780-3928-11e9-9f33-1d8e31b8bd65.png)


Catherine also produces a similar issue, though the upscale filter is working as intended there, and the line repetition is not exactly in the middle of the image, but a bit below.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/53356485-d0bdfe00-392b-11e9-91e8-5df68cbfeb32.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10439488/53356492-d61b4880-392b-11e9-9e94-0a461d6af3fd.png)

In the tunnel section of the second half of the first level (Shopping District), a light reverb effect is supposed to be applied to the audio.
What happens instead in rpcs3 sounds like the reverb effect, but without the proper decay/cutoff needed, so the audio becomes excessively loud and clips.
Correct behavior can be seen here: https://youtu.be/B9ZO_XCSsuQ?t=301
(the footage is from the xbox 360 version, but the audio effect is essentially identical as far as I can tell compared with my real PS3)

System specs: i7-7700k, GTX 1080 Ti, Windows 10
Happens on any graphics or audio backend.
As far as I can tell, it also happens on any PPU/SPU mode.

I didn't notice anything interesting that seemed like it would be related in the log.

Some games write to the GET command destination data a little after execution the command and before its supposed to actually complete on a real ps3.
On rpcs3 all commands are executed immediatly if no barrier mask is blocking them causing data loss.
known list of affected games:

[Narco Terror [NPUB31225]](https://forums.rpcs3.net/thread-179533-post-299703.html#pid299703)
[The Expendables 2 Videogame [NPEB00923]](https://forums.rpcs3.net/thread-179554.html)

The solution would be to emulate the delay in mfc transfers using command execution cycles latency in a saperate mfc thread.

When I play Persona 5 for (usually) 45 minutes the log says "E {rsx::thread} RSX: nv406e::semaphore_acquire has timed out. semaphore_address=0x40300510x*seconds elapsed since this entry appeared*" and drops down to be seemingly locked to 1fps (sometimes goes slightly over, usually stays under it). When I do not enter a Palace, it doesnt seem to be happening at all or instead of crashing after 45 mins crashing after 1 hour and a half, so to trigger it I think I need to be in a Palace. This has so far happened in every palace I have been to (the first three). My theory is that it has to be something that happens within every Palace (the area transition, battles, the Metaverse footsteps [I really suspect this one since it has some visual bugs], etc.). I tried using different builds, which didnt work. Other things I tried include enabling Force CPU Blit, using strict mode, disabling all the patches and changing the Driver Recovery Timeout. The build Im using currently is 7405, the one I used when AniLeo (on Reddit) suggested me to download a newer one is 7439 (I currently use the older one because the newer one instead of crashing after 45 mins crashes after exactly 10 mins, I dont know why but I made sure that the settings are the same as on the older one).

Specs: 


Processor: Intel Core i5 4670K

RAM: 8Gb DDR3

GPU: Radeon R9 200 Series (280, not X)

OS: Windows 10


If you wish to know more, heres a [config.yml download](https://mega.nz/#!rjY11QqA!UHLH3U-RpMMS8jNf5ZVuYWi5Yt_Hbk9XUetO2pOWLx4), the [RPCS3 Log](https://mega.nz/#!rzo0XIxK!ocWKLB5d84Szalj_T5QrB2APFqZ6-oSwM2POrayzhAM) and my previous [Reddit discussion](https://www.reddit.com/r/rpcs3/comments/9kv85o/questions_thread_20181001_to_20181015/e7mywzi) with AniLeo.

Solution - turning off Use GPU Texture Scaling fixed it.

A null-deference happens in the configuration dialog for evdev controllers if the controller's event device disappears.
This happened to me after killing xboxdrv during an attempt to get a Dualshock 3 controller to work (everything but the dpad _seems_ to be working so far!) but I have generalized the steps to reproduce.

The exact error message: `Segfault reading location 0000000000000000 at 0000000000d1d4e2.`

Version: 0.0.5.r441.5c9d0e4b4 (commit 5c9d0e4b46074b56e0bf2fb4a192ee3793d868f3)
System: Arch Linux x86_64, kernel 4.16.13

Steps to reproduce:
- Plug in a controller.
- Go to Configuration->Pads.  Select "Evdev" for any player, and select the appropriate device.
- Click configure.
- With the configuration window open, disconnect the controller.

Expected outcome: A specific warning or error, or perhaps nothing at all (i.e. the program continues to function).

Metabug for tracking remaining bugs with https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/pull/4011
Known issues:
- [x] vulkan can assert randomly when rendering a dialog
- [x] only ASCII text is supported
- [x] code quality: refactoring of some methods into separate helpers is sorely needed to remove hacks in rsx core

Hi there, it seems that RPCS3 seems to have a lot of problems with file paths when I try to use RetroArch PS3 on the emulator. RetroArch PS3 was made with the real PS3 SDK instead of PSL1GHT. Version of RPCS3 used: **v0.0.4-6209-d8ae94df Alpha** Further information provided - I use PSGL for graphics, I use stb_font for rendering the font glyphs, and I am using the runtime Cg compiler to load shaders on the fly from source. Here is a log file - https://hastebin.com/bosotizeca.js Graphics problems: * The icons don't show up, presumably because all the file system accesses are failing. * The font seems to be corrupted. This is what it looks like right now - This is how it should look like instead (screenshot taken on PC with Cg shader backend) - **How to test this** Download the latest version of RetroArch for PS3 here - https://buildbot.libretro.com/stable/1.6.9/playstation/ps3/ https://buildbot.libretro.com/stable/1.6.9/playstation/ps3/RetroArch.PS3.CEX.PS3.pkg NOTE - It seems RPCS3 isn't yet capable of dealing with DEX debug SELFs. Tried using it but I couldn't get it to boot up so I had to resort to the CEX build instead. Install the pkg in RPCS3. Start it up. It should auto default to one core out of the package. **Source** All of our source code for the PS3 port is publicly available on our repository - https://github.com/libretro/RetroArch Let me help you further along and point you to some of the PS3-specific code (beyond these files, all the normal codepaths that would normally get used on PC are used too here) - **File I/O code specific to PS3 ** https://github.com/libretro/RetroArch/blob/master/frontend/drivers/platform_ps3.c This file sets up all the filesystem paths - say, where to get the assets directory from, where to get the cores from, etc. https://github.com/libretro/RetroArch/blob/master/libretro-common/file/retro_dirent.c This file has some PS3-specific code for iterating over files. **Graphics code specific to PS3 ** https://github.com/libretro/RetroArch/blob/master/gfx/drivers/gl.c Basically the PS3 reuses the same GL driver as on PC. The only differences is that HAVE_PSGL, HAVE_OPENGLES are defined, so it employs some of the PSGL-optimized codepaths. For instance, it uses texture references which is some special construct available only in PSGL. More PS3-specific code can be found in the renderchain file here - https://github.com/libretro/RetroArch/blob/master/gfx/drivers_renderchain/gl2_renderchain.c Hopefully this information was helpful, and hopefully it will help make RPCS3 an even better PS3 emulator! I'd be very glad if we could start using RPCS3 as a debugger for our PS3 port personally.

RPCS3 v0.0.4-14-gc435b328, FreeBSD 12-CURRENT, LLVM 4.0.1 (OS packaged LLVM, which is built with assertions enabled).

When a game does not have previously cached PPU code (right after compilation), it launches successfully.

When a game does have cached code, RPCS3 crashes on game launch:

```
Assertion failed: (ObjectBufferMap.find(Key) == ObjectBufferMap.end() && "Second attempt to perform debug registration."), function NotifyObjectEmitted, file /wrkdirs/usr/ports/devel/llvm40/work/llvm-4.0.1.src/lib/ExecutionEngine/GDBRegistrationListener.cpp, line 167.
```

Other projects have hit this assertion: https://sft.its.cern.ch/jira/browse/ROOT-7741

`GDBRegistrationListener` is used by MCJIT by default, looks like there's no way to unregister it (created in the constructor without saving a reference anywhere, and the vector of listeners is private).

TROPUSR.DAT needs to be regenerated or updated after a DLC was installed.

rpcs3 will crash on opening the trophy manager otherwise because the TROPUSR.DAT only contains the info for the old trophy count, ignoring the newly added trophies that are tried to be loaded into the manager nonetheless.

Maybe of interest (from ps3devwiki):

> To avoid corruption when a new trophyset for the same game is installed (e.g: by installing a game patch containing new trophyes), the system renames the previous install folder by adding a _BU_ (its a Back Up) before the name of the folder e.g: _BU_NPWR00001. Then the new trophyset is installed in the default path e.g: NPWR00001
> 
> Only 2 trophysets of the same game can be stored at any time, the older one is always inside the _BU_ folder and the XMB only loads the one inside the default path (without _BU_)

Also, when Loading existing trophy data we should load the config first and add to that data from our user trophy data, in case we have old data that is missing information, which will currently only be updated by workarounds.

![errorcontrol](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32544363/31229600-76b9908c-aa0b-11e7-92ff-3cca60d22705.png)

The armor of the characters  are blank, the problem appears on Vulkan and OGL. The game runs stable at 30 FPS. 

[RPCS3.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1355924/RPCS3.log.gz)
![sem titulo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30375393/31178084-5a186b92-a8ee-11e7-88da-a3eaea1e58b6.jpg)

Currently FCMPO has equal implementation as FCMPU.

[Whenever [11] appears on comparison](https://github.com/RPCS3/ps3autotests/blob/master/tests/cpu/ppu_float_compare/ppu_float_compare.expected), it returns 00001000 on getFPSCR(), which is the correct value for FCMPU, but not for FCMPO.
On a real PS3, this value is A0081000 on FCMPO. Since we fall back to using the same implemention of FCMPU, we're obtaining the wrong value here when using FCMPO.

Tested on Recompiler (LLVM), everything else besides that scenario is accurate. 

**Note:** On Interpreters on RPCS3, the sample always returns 00000000 on getFPSCR(). Something is wrong there as well.

Verified with [ppu_float_compare](https://github.com/RPCS3/ps3autotests/tree/master/tests/cpu/ppu_float_compare) on latest RPCS3 and physical PS3.

I found out that starting Journey with SPU Interpreter (Precise) allows it to go ingame (but seems to have issues uploading the textures, so it  doesn't show any 3D graphics).

![7d08ed8adc6f603a08b59c99cfb1f051](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8772233/30756295-6d894598-9fca-11e7-9eca-20ebdf5a22a7.png)

I tested the PR #3388, but it doesn't prevent the halt.

[RPCS3.log.gz](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1325305/RPCS3.log.gz)

P.D: The faulty instruction is FM (Float multiply) in SPU fast and ASMJIT. If I make SPU Fast to use the Precise implementation, the issue is solved. I have isolated the output of the instruction in one specific thread for each of the interpreters, making clear that it gives different outputs for specific inputs (NaN, and inf).

Here is a zip with both outputs: [SPU_Comparison.zip](https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/files/1349600/SPU_Comparison.zip)

For example, in SPU Fast:
```
anyNumber(included 0) * inf = inf
```
In SPU Precise:
```
anyNumber * inf = NaN
```

For any filename that is non-null but does not conform to the regex in vfs::get - such as relative paths - the CELL_ENOTMOUNTED error is returned. This is incorrect if compared to a PS3. The error should be E_NOENT or similar as some games assign the not-mounted error a special meaning and retry the access in hope that the device becomes available again.

For example:
- The Darkness demo tries to access a relative non-existing file on startup and keeps retrying the access indefinitely when "not mounted" is returned.
- Timeshift BLES00159 complains that the disc is ejected on startup when the "not mounted" error code is returned for a non-valid relative file access.

From what I can see the PS3 only returns not mounted errors for non-relative paths (e.g. starting with a "/").

This issue is different from #3062 since the error is justified. The returned error code is wrong though.

>RSX: ERROR: [DS] Code 155191008 : vkCreateFramebuffer(): VkFramebufferCreateInfo attachment #0 has format of VK_FORMAT_B8G8R8A8_SRGB that does not match the format of VK_FORMAT_R5G6B5_UNORM_PACK16 used by the corresponding attachment for renderPass (0x53). The spec valid usage text states 'Any given element of pAttachments must have been created with an VkFormat value that matches the VkFormat specified by the corresponding VkAttachmentDescription in renderPass' (https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.0/html/vkspec.html#VUID-VkFramebufferCreateInfo-pAttachments-00880)

```

This is thrown when the game passes width = 0 and height = 0 to the Render. Games where this happen tend to function on OpenGL, but not on Vulkan nor on D3D12 (which is known to be extremely outdated anyways).

Hi,

as discussed in http://www.emunewz.net/forum/showthread.php?tid=178993, I'm experiencing some massive graphical issues with Ni no Kuni: Wrath of the White Witch. ssshadow told me it might be worth to file a bug report along with a RenderDoc trace, so here we go.

I made a detailed post about the current status of the game and my configuration [here](http://www.emunewz.net/forum/showthread.php?tid=179175). TL;DR: The game shows massive flickering (especially 3D objects) and missing graphics (in fact, most 3D objects are missing; 2D seems to be fine for the most part). It doesn't seem to matter if the camera is moving; the flickering persists even when the game is paused. This affects OpenGL, Vulkan and DX12, although DX12 seems to be marginally better.

My configuration is as follows:

i7 4770k @ 3.5 GHz, Geforce GTX 1070 (driver 378.49), 16 GB DDR3, Win10 64 bit

rpcs3-v0.0.1-2017-03-03-48b05838_win64
PPU decoder: Interpreter (fast); SPU decoder: Recompiler (ASMJIT)
LLE modules extracted from the PS3UPDATE.PUP that came with Ni no Kuni & automatically selected by RPCS3; for the list of modules I used in previous versions with identical results, see http://www.emunewz.net/forum/showthread.php?tid=179175
Video settings: OpenGL @ 1280x720 w/ Vsync, Frame limit set to Auto; Use Legacy OpenGL Buffers checked

Interestingly, the RenderDoc trace looks MUCH cleaner (fewer missing objects, especially the background) than the actual RPCS3 output, so I've attached a screenshot of the same frame to highlight the difference.

The attached zip file contains my log, the RenderDoc trace and the RPCS3 screenshot of the captured frame. Hope that's all the information you need for now. Let me know if anything's missing.

This is a tracker for issues related to the shader decompiler
### List of issues so far
- [x] Attempted swizzle on special function calls e.g sqrt https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/1894
- [ ] Failure to swizzle component result in vertex texture fetch https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/1890
- [x] Broken handling of ARL vector opcode https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/1913
- [x] Broken handling of DDX/DDY swizzle #https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/2002
- [x] Broken swizzle of some grouped functions e.g (fn).xyz #1989

Vulkan now leaks old render target storage resources. This can happen very quickly causing crashes.

In Silent Hill 3 RSX uses some 1280x720 texture with 12 mipmaps. log2(1280) is 11 so there is a mipmap level that shouldn't be here.

It looks like DX12 doesn't mind, I'm not sure about Vulkan. However in GL this leads to invalid texture. Capping mipmap level fixes the issue.

All backend are affected since they use rsx::texture::mipmap() to get mipmap count.

In Operating Systems that do NOT support DirectX 12 like Windows 7, if Vulkan is selected as the Renderer, RPCS3 will assume we picked DX12 and crash.
That's due to the fact DX12 isn't showed in the list and Vulkan takes its place in the list.
Null, OpenGL, Vulkan instead of Null, OpenGL, DirectX 12, Vulkan

After updating wxwidgets source on my pc, builds do not blit contents to the framebuffer correctly under opengl; specifically, if the internal rendering resolution does not match the window dimensions. glBlitFramebuffer fails with invalid_operation. wxWidgets glcanvas creation has undergone some rewrites that may cause this. Appveyor builds do not suffer from this issue for some reason, so it might just be my local branches affected. Noted on AMD hardware.

In resogun, OpenGL shows some corruption where the bottom half of the screen is green. This is because the video player uploads the component textures separately, but 2 of the 3 channels have the wrong pitch encoded in the rsx::texture object. The textures in question are 8-bit single channel textures, but two of them give pitch() as double the width which makes no sense. Of course, setting the unpack settings to use the given width instead of pitch fixes this but I feel this is hacky.

I'm doing something wrong or is a linker error?

I think I found why PPU LLVM crashes at exit, it looks like RecompilationEngine (which stores all the ExecutionEngine and frees virtual memory at destruction) is destroyed before the other PPU Thread that relies on it.
If I store the ExecutionEngine in a static variable and comment out the virtual mem free operation it doesn't crash anymore when closing rpcs3.

I found why in SH3 HD there is neither shadow nor light, sometimes it looks like the data between transform and shader stage doesn't properly map.

For instance the shader program responsible of static geometry reads a "tc9" input while the corresponding transform program doesn't write to tc9. Instead, it writes to dst_reg6 (mapped to clip distance data) in a non traditionnal way, and if I manually change the shader program to read dst_reg6 instead of tc9 (which maps to tc16...) I have correct light and shadow. However there are still glitches if I mimic this behavior for all shader program, it looks like tc9 is not always mapped to the same reg.

On the other hand there is the NV4097_SET_VERTEX_ATTRIB_OUTPUT_MASK  command that we don't use, that might perhaps have the info but I don't know how.

The game has some intro logos, but before main menu the game complains about "Sixaxis Wireless Controller not detected" and doesn't go further. Log does not provide any explicit info about the problem (as far as I can see), but I attach it since you will probably see more than me.
